chargeHist.descr: Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal)

result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI 5th and Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th). The defendant was found guilty of OWI 5th and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th) was dismissed by the court.

  • Vanessa R. Wagner was found guilty of OWI 5th, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Vanessa R. Wagner

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: any probation now serving.

Per Statute 343.301(g) your operating privileges for operation of Class D vehicles will require that vehicles owned and/or driven by you be equipped with an ignition interlock device.  Must install a mandatory Ignition Interlock Device when defendant obtains an occupational license or regular license.  There is a $50 ignition interlock surcharge imposed.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  If the defendant is placed on probation or released to extended supervision, IT IS ORDERED that the defendant pay supervision fees as determined by the Department of Corrections.

If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  If the defendant is placed on probation or released to extended supervision, IT IS ORDERED that the defendant pay supervision fees as determined by the Department of Corrections.

Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.
Seek and maintain employment.  Not to terminate employment without agent's prior approval.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by her agent.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Credit for 3 days, if revoked.

timeConds.notes: Sentence to start on or before September 2, 2016 at 6:00 pm.  May serve on EMP, according to jail rules.  Sobrietor, at agent's discretion.

records.addlTxt:
Defendant plead guilty Count 1.  Dismiss, but read in Count 2.  Count 3 dismissed by operation of law.  Dismiss and read in 15TR2946, 2891, 2890.  Court recited the charge and possible penalties on the count she plead to.   Defendant understood. Prior OWI convictions confirmed by the court with the defendant and Attorney Cohen.   Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Felony warnings given.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea.   Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily, and intelligently entered her plea and waived her constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Found guilty of OWI 5th, contrary to 346.63(1)(a).  PAC  232.  Joint recommendation for: Probation for 3 years.  $600 fine, plus costs.  Jail 9 months.   EMP ok, according to jail rules.   The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  DNA sample and surcharge.    Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  Subject to random testing.  2 year DL revocation and IID.  Defendant exercised her right to allocution.  

Court ordered:  sentence withheld, 3 years probation.  Concurrent with probation now serving.   $600 fine, plus costs.  Jail 1 year.   May serve on EMP, according to jail rules.  Sobritor at agent's discretion.  Start on or before September 2, 2016 at 6 pm.  The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  DNA sample and surcharge.    Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  Subject to random testing by her agent.  2 year DL revocation and IID.  Seek and maintain employment.  Not to terminate without agent's prior approval.  Credit for 3 days, if revoked.  Court not willing to exempt stored car from IID requirement.
Reading of the information waived.
Information filed with the court.

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Cohen.  Court questioned defendant on her understanding of the waiver of preliminary hearing.  She stated she understood.  Court found that the defendant knowingly and intelligently waived her right to have a preliminary hearing.

Waiver of Prelim on August 8, 2016 at 10:00 am.
Plea hearing on August 8, 2016 at 10:00 am.

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Attorney Cohen appeared by telephone.  Defendant appeared in person.  Defendant completed in-patient treatment.  In aftercare program with HCN.  Set for waiver of preliminary hearing/plea 8/8/16 at 10:00 am.
Status conference at 05-16-2016 03:00 pm

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Attorney Cohen appeared.  Defendant failed to appear at the plea hearing.  Defendant may have misunderstood about the hearing today.  Defendant is on a waiting list for a 30 day inpatient treatment program.  State not requesting a warrant.  Set STC 5/16 at 3 pm.  Attorney Cohen may appear by telephone to give the court an update.
from Attorney Cohen.
Plea hearing at 02-15-2016 01:30 pm

Pre-trial conference at 10-21-2015 10:00 am.
Status conference at 11-16-2015 03:00 pm.
Court confirmed that the defendant wishes to waive the time limits.  Defendant understood.  Court finds defendant knowingly and intelligently waived time limits for holding the preliminary hearing.
records.descr: Waiver of time limits for preliminary hearing

records.addlTxt: DA Gerald Fox appears for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and Attorney Cohen appeared by telephone.  Waive reading of the complaint.  PTC set for 10/21 and STC set for 11/16.  Bond continued.
Adjourned initial appearance at 09-28-2015 09:30 am

ADA Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  Attorney Cohen appeared by telephone.  Defendant FTA for bond hearing.  Attorney Cohen retained on 9/9.  He did request that the AIA be rescheduled to 9/28/15.  State does not object to the warrant being quashed.  Reinstate signature bond.  AIA set for 9/28/15 at 9:30 am.  Attorney Cohen may appear by telephone.
ADA Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  Defendant did not appear for the adjourned initial appearance.  Warrant authorized if not in custody.

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.  Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly reinstated in the State of Wisconsin.

Defendant appeared by video from Jackson County Jail.  No attorney present.  Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant acknowledges receipt of complaint and states she will get an attorney.  DA Fox requests a $5000 sig bond with conditions:  Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.  Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly reinstated in the State of Wisconsin..  Court orders bond as requested and sets adjourned initial appearance for 9-14-15 at 9:30.
Adjourned initial appearance at 09-14-2015 09:30 am

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.  Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly reinstated in the State of Wisconsin.
